para.p:
Whenever we speak about a vector space in this note we mean a vector space over
R
. If
X
is a topological vector space then we denote by
X *
the set of all continuous linear maps
→ X R
.
X *
is called the dual space of
X
, and is itself a vector space. 1 1 footnote 1 In this note, we are following the presentation of some results in Charalambos D. Aliprantis and Kim C. Border, Infinite Dimensional Analysis: A Hitchhiker’s Guide, third ed., chapter 7. Three other sources for material on subdifferentials are: Jean-Paul Penot, Calulus Without Derivatives, chapter 3; Viorel Barbu and Teodor Precupanu, Convexity and Optimization in Banach Spaces, fourth ed., §2.2, pp. 82–125; and Jean-Pierre Aubin, Optima and Equilibria: An Introduction to Nonlinear Analysis, second ed., chapter 4, pp. 57–73.

X

X *

λ

at
x
if 2 2 footnote 2
=
+ ∞ ∞
∞

=

∞
- ∞

- ∞ ∞
is nonsense; if

=

- ∞
and
=

∞
.

Math.text: formulae@(f * y >= f * x + lambda * (y - x), y element-of X)

para.p:
The subdifferential of
f
at
x
is the set of all subgradients of
f
at
x
and is denoted by
⁢

( x )

X

X *

:
∂ f
→ X
2
X *

≠

( x )
∅
, we say that
f

x
.

It is immediate that if there is some
y
such that
=

( y )
- ∞

Math.text: formulae@(partial-differential@(f) * x = cases@(X ^ *, f * x = - infinity, empty-set, f * x > - infinity), x element-of X)

para.p:
Thus, little is lost if we prove statements about subdifferentials of functions that do not take the value
- ∞
.

f * y

absent = f * x + ((1 - t) * lambda _ 1 + t * lambda _ 2) * (y - x)
absent = f * x + ((1 - t) * lambda _ 1 + t * lambda _ 2) * (y - x)

If
X

is a function, we say that
f
is proper if it does not take only the value
∞
and never takes the value
- ∞
. It is unusual to talk merely about proper functions rather than proper convex functions; we do so to make clear how convexity is used in the results we prove.

Let

In other words, the weak-* topology on
X *
is the topology of pointwise convergence. We now prove that at each point in the effective domain of a proper function on a topological vector space, the subdifferential is a weak-* closed subset of the dual space. 3 3 footnote 3 cf. Charalambos D. Aliprantis and Kim C. Border, Infinite Dimensional Analysis: A Hitchhiker’s Guide, third ed., p. 265, Theorem 7.13.

para.p:
If
A
is a nonempty subset of a topological vector space
X
and
∈ x A
, we say that
x

A
if there is some nonzero
∈ λ
X *
for which
x
is a minimizer or a maximizer of
λ
over
A
. Moreover,
x

λ
over
A

x

- λ
over
A
. Thus, if we know that
x
is a support point of a set
A
, then we have at our disposal both that
x
is a minimizer of some nonzero element of
X *
over
A
and that
x
is a maximizer of some nonzero element of
X *
over
A

If
x

A
and

{
∈ y X
:

A

{
∈ y X
:

⁢ λ y
⁢ λ x

is equivalent to saying that there is some
∈ y A
such that
≠

In the following lemma, we show that the support points of a set
A
are contained in the boundary
∂ A
of the set.

The following lemma gives conditions under which a boundary point of a set is a proper support point of the set. 4 4 footnote 4 Charalambos D. Aliprantis and Kim C. Border, Infinite Dimensional Analysis: A Hitchhiker’s Guide, third ed., p. 259, Lemma 7.7.

p.text:
If
X
is a topological vector space,
C
is a convex subset of
X
that has nonempty interior, and
∈ x
∩ C
∂ C
, then
C
is properly supported at
x
.

para.p:
The Hahn-Banach separation theorem 5 5 footnote 5 Gert K. Pedersen, Analysis Now, revised printing, p. 65, Theorem 2.4.7. tells us that if
A
and
B
are disjoint nonempty convex subsets of
X
and
A
is open then there is some
∈ λ
X *
and some
∈ t R
such that

Math.text: formulae@(lambda * a less t less= lambda * b, formulae@(a element-of A, b element-of B))

para.p:
Check that the interior of a convex set in a topological vector space is convex, and hence that we can apply the Hahn-Banach separation theorem to
{ x }
and
C ∘
: as
x
belongs to the boundary of
C
it does not belong to the interior of
C
, so
{ x }
and
C ∘
are disjoint nonempty convex sets. Thus, there is some
∈ λ
X *
and some
∈ t R
such that
⁢ λ y
< t ≤

for all

C ∘

≤

for all
∈ y C

≠ λ 0
because of the strict inequality for the interior. As
∈ x C

x

λ
over
C

≠ λ 0
this means that
x
is a support point of
C
. But
C ∘
is nonempty and if
∈ y
C ∘
then
<
⁢ λ x
⁢ λ y
, hence
x
is a proper support point of
C
. ∎

We now prove conditions under which a function is subdifferentiable at a point, i.e., under which the subdifferential at that point is nonempty. 6 6 footnote 6 Charalambos D. Aliprantis and Kim C. Border, Infinite Dimensional Analysis: A Hitchhiker’s Guide, third ed., p. 265, Theorem 7.12.

para.p:
Because
f
is convex, the set
⁢ dom f
is convex, and the interior of a convex set in a topological vector space is convex so
(
⁢ dom f
)
∘
is convex.
f
is proper so it does not take the value
- ∞
, and on
⁢ dom f
it does not take the value
∞
, hence
f
is finite on
⁢ dom f
. But for a finite convex function on an open convex set in a topological vector space, being continuous at a point is equivalent to being continuous on the set, and is also equivalent to being bounded above on an open neighborhood of the point. 7 7 footnote 7 Charalambos D. Aliprantis and Kim C. Border, Infinite Dimensional Analysis: A Hitchhiker’s Guide, third ed., p. 188, Theorem 5.43. Therefore,
f
is continuous on
(
⁢ dom f

∘

V

(
⁢ dom f
